title: 110_hr5515
content: The amendment to Section 233(e) of the Act allows agreements to enter into force after 60 days of transmittal to Congress, excluding non-working days. Documents and reports supporting the agreement must be delivered to both Houses of Congress simultaneously. Whenever an agreement under this section is transmitted to Congress, copies of the document must be delivered to both Houses on the same day. The document must also include a determination by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration on the impact of the agreement on the social security system over a 75-year period. The Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration will determine if there will be a net reduction in the actuarial balance of the social security system over a 75-year period due to the agreement. The actuarial balance is the difference between the income rate and cost rate over the period, and taxable payroll refers to total wages to be paid. The term 'actuarial balance' is the difference between adjusted summarized income rate and cost rate over a period. 'Taxable payroll' refers to total wages and self-employment income for a period. 'Adjusted summarized income rate' is the ratio of trust fund balance and total income to taxable payroll. 'Adjusted summarized cost rate' is the ratio of total cost to taxable payroll over a period. The trust fund balance is the combined balance of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The income from taxes refers to the total income from taxes during a period. The adjusted summarized cost rate is the ratio of the sum of the present value of the cost during such period plus the present value of the targeted trust fund balance to the present value of the taxable payroll for the years for such period. The term 'trust fund balance' refers to the combined balance of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. 'Income from taxes' represents the amounts deposited in the Trust Funds as appropriations based on taxes under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. 'Cost' refers to disbursements from the Trust Funds during a period, including benefit payments and special monthly payments to certain uninsured individuals. The term 'cost' in this context refers to disbursements from the Trust Funds during a period, including benefit payments, special monthly payments to certain uninsured individuals, administrative expenses, and payments for vocational rehabilitation services for disabled beneficiaries. The term 'target trust fund balance' refers to the balance needed at the end of a 75-year period to maintain a 100 percent OASDI trust fund ratio. The Chief Actuary uses the intermediate assumptions of the Board of Trustees for making determinations. The Chief Actuary uses the Board of Trustees' assumptions to determine the target trust fund balance for maintaining a 100 percent OASDI trust fund ratio. An agreement under this section will not take effect if a disapproving bill is enacted within 60 days. If the Chief Actuary predicts a net reduction in the actuarial balance for the 75-year period, the agreement may be affected. The Chief Actuary's determination on an agreement under this section may lead to a net reduction in the actuarial balance for the 75-year period, affecting the agreement's entry into force. If the reduction is at least 0.005 percent of the present value of taxable payroll, a bill approving the agreement must be enacted within 60 days for it to take effect. The agreement will only enter into force if a bill approving it is enacted within 60 days. Congress has the power to establish rules for the approval process, superseding any inconsistent rules. During a 60-day period, Congress can consider a bill for the approval or disapproval of an agreement, with the majority or minority leader introducing it as a matter of highest privilege. This process supersedes any inconsistent rules in the House. During a 60-day period, Congress can consider a bill for the approval or disapproval of an agreement under this section, with the majority or minority leader introducing it as a matter of highest privilege. The agreement shall not be subject to amendment after transmittal to each House of Congress. The amendment made by this subsection applies to agreements transmitted to Congress on or after the enactment of this Act. The amendment made by this subsection applies to agreements establishing totalization arrangements under section 233 of the Social Security Act, transmitted to Congress after the enactment of this Act. A special rule applies to agreements signed by the Commissioner of Social Security in June 2004. Agreements between the social security systems of different countries signed by the Commissioner of Social Security in June 2004 and transmitted to Congress after September 1, 2007, will not be in force until after the enactment of this Act. They will only enter into force as provided in section 233(e) of the Social Security Act. The agreement between social security systems of different countries signed in June 2004 will only be in force after the enactment of the Act, as outlined in section 233(e) of the Social Security Act. Additionally, biennial reports to Congress regarding ongoing operation of totalization agreements will be required. Biennial Oversight Reports are required for ongoing operation of totalization agreements as outlined in the Social Security Act. The Commissioner of Social Security must submit biennial reports to Congress evaluating the operation of totalization agreements, including changes in benefit costs and contributions, as well as information on fraudulent receipt of benefits. The biennial reports to Congress evaluate the operation of totalization agreements, including changes in benefit costs, contributions, fraudulent benefit receipt, integrity of data, and potential future deviations from cost estimates. The Commissioner of Social Security shall submit reports on totalization agreements, including information on demographic trends and deviations from cost estimates, by December 31, 2008. SEC. 203. SUSPENSION OF BENEFITS FOR INDIVIDUALS REMOVED FROM THE UNITED STATES. Section 202(n)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to state that no lump sum death payment will be made to an individual after being notified of their removal from the United States by the Commissioner of Social Security, Attorney General, or Secretary of Homeland Security. These amendments apply to individuals who have been removed from the country. The amendments made by this section apply to individuals notified of their removal from the United States by the Attorney General or the Secretary of Homeland Security. The effective date is after the twelfth month following the enactment of this Act.
